answers.q: how much potassium is in glucosamine sulfate potassium chloride
answers.a: In the common “glucosamine sulfate 2KCl” form, potassium is about 13% by weight—so 1500 mg of the salt provides roughly 190–200 mg of potassium; check your product’s label for the exact amount.

answers.q: how to use potassium sulfate fertilizer
answers.a: Apply according to a soil test, as potassium sulfate supplies about 50% K2O and 17–18% sulfur; it can be broadcast and incorporated, side‑dressed, or fertigated and is preferred where chloride must be limited. Always follow local agronomic guidance and the product label to avoid overapplication.
Yes—potassium sulfate is moderately soluble in water (about 11 g per 100 g water at 25°C), with solubility increasing at higher temperatures; it is essentially insoluble in ethanol.

Aluminum potassium sulfate (potassium alum, KAl(SO4)2·12H2O) is a double sulfate salt used as a firming agent, mordant, and astringent; as a food additive it is listed separately from potassium sulfate (E522 vs. E515).

Potassium aluminum sulfate—potassium alum, KAl(SO4)2·12H2O—is the same compound as aluminum potassium sulfate, a double salt used as a firming agent and pickling “alum,” distinct from potassium sulfate (E515).
